analyzeResult.content:
-- Original Message --
From:
Favale, Cheryl J.
Sent:
To:
Thursday, December 27, 2001 12:10 PM
Fuller, Stuart G .; Teitelbaum, Shari Z .; Saloun, Tom; Katz, David H .; Falvo, Jeff J.
Subject:
PPPs
I've now had the opportunity to read a handful of PPPs from your groups and here are a few suggestions to keep in mind when you are writing and/or reviewing PPPs:
. When reading the documents make sure that there is enough detail around the situation and demonstrated behaviors - the model we recommend includes:
. describe the situation
. describe the task given to employee
describe the action taken by employee (with behavioral examples)
. describe the result - or impact
PPP's should be written to the employee, not in third person
.. Check to make sure messages are in line with final PPP rating and the "boxes" at the end of the document (i.e., if you say "integrity, trust, and respect" is a "development need", please ensure something in the document illustrates this)
. Nothing personal should be included in PPP document (i.e., if someone was out on a medical leave it should just state "leave" or don't mention it at all).
I will review the forms as needed, but I would ask that you (the directors) review first and then if you need assistance or feel I need to look at something, please let me know. I have also been reviewing all the ME and UP's and providing feedback to the managers. That should continue.
Finally, as the PPP forms are completed, employees are indicating their mobilities. Please ensure that your managers are capturing mobility ratings in a list which can be sent to me later on. Mobility will be critical as we conduct Advancement Planning in the future. If a list is not kept, we'll need to go through all 60 PPPs to get the mobilities which will be a waste of resources.
Feel free to pass this note on as appropriate.
Thanks!
Cheryl Favale HR Manager - Decision Support NYO ext. 3316
124
2085269332
